2. Unity. The physical separation of NAEB and
particularly of National Educational Radio from
the network function creates inefficiencies.
Correspondence intended for the network is routed
to the Washington office and vice versa. Tele¬
phone and personal inquiries are mis-directed
because of the physical separation. Adminis¬
tration of the network by the manager is hamp¬
ered by lack of contact with the NER Executive
Director and the balance of the NAEB staff. The
move would result in increased supervision, im¬
proved coordination and proper control.
3. Distribution. Currently, program materials
are distributed on tape by mail. From Urbana,
most materials are routed through the Chicago
post office for dispatch. Distribution would be
enhanced by locating the network in a metropolitan
area with superior postal services. Geographically,
it appears that the mid-western location holds
certain advantages. Our examination of patterns
of mail distribution lead us to believe that, in
fact, the speed will increase when the tape net¬
work is in proximity with a key postal center.
This is particularly true in regard to air mail
distribution of programs containing material
requiring rapid dissemination.
4. Production Facilities. At present, the net¬
work lacks the necessary capacity to produce or
edit program material. In the main, this work is
done prior to the arrival of the tape in Urbana.
Production facilities would be available from one
or more educational radio stations in the Wash¬
ington, D. C. area.
